Create a List of Evaluation Metrics

wtl.measures.Rd

This function creates a data frame containing the names of evaluation metrics, their corresponding types, and the total count of metrics. Each metric is categorized by its type, which indicates whether a higher or lower value represents better performance.

wtl.measures()

Value

A data frame with the following columns:

  • names: A character vector of metric names.

  • type: An integer vector representing the evaluation type of each metric.

The total number of metrics equals the length of the names vector.

Details

The type vector categorizes metrics as follows:

  • 1: Metrics where a higher value indicates better performance.

  • 0: Metrics where a lower value indicates better performance.

Below is a summary of the metrics and their evaluation types:

Metric NameTypeInterpretation
accuracy1higher is better
auprc_macro1higher is better
auprc_micro1higher is better
auprc_samples1higher is better
auprc_weighted1higher is better
average_precision1higher is better
clp0lower is better
coverage0lower is better
f11higher is better
hamming_loss0lower is better
macro_auc1higher is better
macro_F11higher is better
macro_precision1higher is better
macro_recall1higher is better
margin_loss0lower is better
micro_auc1higher is better
micro_F11higher is better
micro_precision1higher is better
micro_recall1higher is better
mlp0lower is better
one_error0lower is better
precision1higher is better
ranking_loss0lower is better
recall1higher is better
roc_auc_macro1higher is better
roc_auc_micro1higher is better
roc_auc_samples1higher is better
roc_auc_weighted1higher is better
subset_accuracy1higher is better
wlp0lower is better

Examples

# Create the data frame of metrics
metric_df <- wtl.measures()

# Display the resulting data frame
print(metric_df)
#>                names type
#> 1           accuracy    1
#> 2        auprc_macro    1
#> 3        auprc_micro    1
